learning:
PhonePe’s payments business looks huge because UPI scale exploded, but the hard part is turning that scale into durable profits. The company built its own data centers instead of renting cloud capacity, which means it pays large upfront costs and then benefits from much lower per-transaction costs once volume is high enough. That creates operating leverage — but only if growth keeps climbing fast enough to absorb depreciation.

A second hidden drag is share‑based compensation. It doesn’t require cash today, but it still dilutes shareholders and can make EBITDA look healthier than the true economic cost of running the business. In other words, PhonePe can look “profitable” on some metrics while still losing money on the bottom line.

So the real insight is that payments scale alone isn’t the finish line. PhonePe’s path to profitability depends on whether it can shift from policy‑sensitive revenue pools and subsidies toward steady merchant and financial‑services income while keeping growth high enough to justify its infrastructure bet.
title: Why PhonePe’s scale isn’t the same as profits
